text: What does laughter mean? What is the basal element in the laughable?
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: What common ground can we find between the grimace of a merry-andrew, a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: play upon words, an equivocal situation in a burlesque and a scene of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: high comedy? What method of distillation will yield us invariably the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: same essence from which so many different products borrow either their
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: obtrusive odour or their delicate perfume? The greatest of thinkers,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: from Aristotle downwards, have tackled this little problem, which has a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: knack of baffling every effort, of slipping away and escaping only to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: bob up again, a pert challenge flung at philosophic speculation. Our
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: excuse for attacking the problem in our turn must lie in the fact that
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: we shall not aim at imprisoning the comic spirit within a definition.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: We regard it, above all, as a living thing. However trivial it may be,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: we shall treat it with the respect due to life. We shall confine
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ourselves to watching it grow and expand. Passing by imperceptible
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: gradations from one form to another, it will be seen to achieve the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: strangest metamorphoses. We shall disdain nothing we have seen. Maybe
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: we may gain from this prolonged contact, for the matter of that,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: something more flexible than an abstract definition,--a practical,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: intimate acquaintance, such as springs from a long companionship. And
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: maybe we may also find that, unintentionally, we have made an
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: acquaintance that is useful. For the comic spirit has a logic of its
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: own, even in its wildest eccentricities. It has a method in its
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: madness. It dreams, I admit, but it conjures up, in its dreams, visions
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: that are at once accepted and understood by the whole of a social
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: group. Can it then fail to throw light for us on the way that human
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: imagination works, and more particularly social, collective, and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: popular imagination? Begotten of real life and akin to art, should it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: not also have something of its own to tell us about art and life?
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: At the outset we shall put forward three observations which we look
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: upon as fundamental. They have less bearing on the actually comic than
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: on the field within which it must be sought.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: I
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: The first point to which attention should be called is that the comic
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: does not exist outside the pale of what is strictly HUMAN. A landscape
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: may be beautiful, charming and sublime, or insignificant and ugly; it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: will never be laughable. You may laugh at an animal, but only because
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: you have detected in it some human attitude or expression. You may
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: laugh at a hat, but what you are making fun of, in this case, is not
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the piece of felt or straw, but the shape that men have given it,--the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: human caprice whose mould it has assumed. It is strange that so
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: important a fact, and such a simple one too, has not attracted to a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: greater degree the attention of philosophers. Several have defined man
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: as "an animal which laughs." They might equally well have defined him
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: as an animal which is laughed at; for if any other animal, or some
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: lifeless object, produces the same effect, it is always because of some
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: resemblance to man, of the stamp he gives it or the use he puts it to.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Here I would point out, as a symptom equally worthy of notice, the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ABSENCE OF FEELING which usually accompanies laughter. It seems as
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: though the comic could not produce its disturbing effect unless it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: fell, so to say, on the surface of a soul that is thoroughly calm and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: unruffled. Indifference is its natural environment, for laughter has no
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: greater foe than emotion. I do not mean that we could not laugh at a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: person who inspires us with pity, for instance, or even with affection,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: but in such a case we must, for the moment, put our affection out of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: court and impose silence upon our pity. In a society composed of pure
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: intelligences there would probably be no more tears, though perhaps
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: there would still be laughter; whereas highly emotional souls, in tune
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and unison with life, in whom every event would be sentimentally
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: prolonged and re-echoed, would neither know nor understand laughter.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Try, for a moment, to become interested in everything that is being
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: said and done; act, in imagination, with those who act, and feel with
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: those who feel; in a word, give your sympathy its widest expansion: as
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: though at the touch of a fairy wand you will see the flimsiest of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: objects assume importance, and a gloomy hue spread over everything. Now
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: step aside, look upon life as a disinterested spectator: many a drama
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: will turn into a comedy. It is enough for us to stop our ears to the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: sound of music, in a room where dancing is going on, for the dancers at
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: once to appear ridiculous. How many human actions would stand a similar
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: test? Should we not see many of them suddenly pass from grave to gay,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: on isolating them from the accompanying music of sentiment? To produce
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the whole of its effect, then, the comic demands something like a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: momentary anesthesia of the heart. Its appeal is to intelligence, pure
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and simple.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: This intelligence, however, must always remain in touch with other
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: intelligences. And here is the third fact to which attention should be
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: drawn. You would hardly appreciate the comic if you felt yourself
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: isolated from others. Laughter appears to stand in need of an echo,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Listen to it carefully: it is not an articulate, clear, well-defined
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: sound; it is something which would fain be prolonged by reverberating
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: from one to another, something beginning with a crash, to continue in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: successive rumblings, like thunder in a mountain. Still, this
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: reverberation cannot go on for ever. It can travel within as wide a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: circle as you please: the circle remains, none the less, a closed one.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Our laughter is always the laughter of a group. It may, perchance, have
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: happened to you, when seated in a railway carriage or at table d'hote,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to hear travellers relating to one another stories which must have been
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comic to them, for they laughed heartily. Had you been one of their
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: company, you would have laughed like them; but, as you were not, you
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: had no desire whatever to do so. A man who was once asked why he did
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: not weep at a sermon, when everybody else was shedding tears, replied:
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: "I don't belong to the parish!" What that man thought of tears would be
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: still more true of laughter. However spontaneous it seems, laughter
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: always implies a kind of secret freemasonry, or even complicity, with
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: other laughers, real or imaginary. How often has it been said that the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: fuller the theatre, the more uncontrolled the laughter of the audience!
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: On the other hand, how often has the remark been made that many comic
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: effects are incapable of translation from one language to another,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: because they refer to the customs and ideas of a particular social
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: group! It is through not understanding the importance of this double
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: fact that the comic has been looked upon as a mere curiosity in which
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the mind finds amusement, and laughter itself as a strange, isolated
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: phenomenon, without any bearing on the rest of human activity. Hence
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: those definitions which tend to make the comic into an abstract
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: relation between ideas: "an intellectual contrast," "a palpable
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: absurdity," etc.,--definitions which, even were they really suitable to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: every form of the comic, would not in the least explain why the comic
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: makes us laugh. How, indeed, should it come about that this particular
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: logical relation, as soon as it is perceived, contracts, expands and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: shakes our limbs, whilst all other relations leave the body unaffected?
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: It is not from this point of view that we shall approach the problem.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: To understand laughter, we must put it back into its natural
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: environment, which is society, and above all must we determine the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: utility of its function, which is a social one. Such, let us say at
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: once, will be the leading idea of all our investigations. Laughter must
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: answer to certain requirements of life in common. It must have a SOCIAL
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: signification.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Let us clearly mark the point towards which our three preliminary
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: observations are converging. The comic will come into being, it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: appears, whenever a group of men concentrate their attention on one of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: their number, imposing silence on their emotions and calling into play
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: nothing but their intelligence. What, now, is the particular point on
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: which their attention will have to be concentrated, and what will here
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: be the function of intelligence? To reply to these questions will be at
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: once to come to closer grips with the problem. But here a few examples
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: have become indispensable.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: burst out laughing. They would not laugh at him, I imagine, could they
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: suppose that the whim had suddenly seized him to sit down on the

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: sort, but continued like a machine in the same straight line. The
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: just where one would expect to find the wide-awake adaptability and the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: nothing but look on, but in the second the mischievous wag intervenes.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: All the same, in both cases the result has been brought about by an
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: external circumstance. The comic is therefore accidental: it remains,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: so to speak, in superficial contact with the person. How is it to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: penetrate within? The necessary conditions will be fulfilled when
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: mechanical rigidity no longer requires for its manifestation a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: stumbling-block which either the hazard of circumstance or human
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: knavery has set in its way, but extracts by natural processes, from its
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: own store, an inexhaustible series of opportunities for externally
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: revealing its presence. Suppose, then, we imagine a mind always
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: thinking of what it has just done and never of what it is doing, like a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: song which lags behind its accompaniment. Let us try to picture to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ourselves a certain inborn lack of elasticity of both senses and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: intelligence, which brings it to pass that we continue to see what is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: no longer visible, to hear what is no longer audible, to say what is no
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: longer to the point: in short, to adapt ourselves to a past and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: therefore imaginary situation, when we ought to be shaping our conduct
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: in accordance with the reality which is present. This time the comic
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: will take up its abode in the person himself; it is the person who will
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: supply it with everything--matter and form, cause and opportunity. Is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: it then surprising that the absent-minded individual--for this is the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: character we have just been describing--has usually fired the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: imagination of comic authors? When La Bruyere came across this
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: particular type, he realised, on analysing it, that he had got hold of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a recipe for the wholesale manufacture of comic effects. As a matter of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: fact he overdid it, and gave us far too lengthy and detailed a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: description of Menalque, coming back to his subject, dwelling and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: expatiating on it beyond all bounds. The very facility of the subject
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: fascinated him. Absentmindedness, indeed, is not perhaps the actual
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: fountain-head of the comic, but surely it is contiguous to a certain
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: stream of facts and fancies which flows straight from the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: fountain-head. It is situated, so to say, on one of the great natural
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: watersheds of laughter.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Now, the effect of absentmindedness may gather strength in its turn.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: There is a general law, the first example of which we have just
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: encountered, and which we will formulate in the following terms: when a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: certain comic effect has its origin in a certain cause, the more
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: natural we regard the cause to be, the more comic shall we find the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: effect. Even now we laugh at absentmindedness when presented to us as a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: simple fact. Still more laughable will be the absentmindedness we have
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: seen springing up and growing before our very eyes, with whose origin
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: we are acquainted and whose life-history we can reconstruct. To choose
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a definite example: suppose a man has taken to reading nothing but
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: romances of love and chivalry. Attracted and fascinated by his heroes,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: his thoughts and intentions gradually turn more and more towards them,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: till one fine day we find him walking among us like a somnambulist. His
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: actions are distractions. But then his distractions can be traced back
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to a definite, positive cause. They are no longer cases of ABSENCE of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: mind, pure and simple; they find their explanation in the PRESENCE of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the individual in quite definite, though imaginary, surroundings.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Doubtless a fall is always a fall, but it is one thing to tumble into a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: well because you were looking anywhere but in front of you, it is quite
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: another thing to fall into it because you were intent upon a star. It
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: was certainly a star at which Don Quixote was gazing. How profound is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the comic element in the over-romantic, Utopian bent of mind! And yet,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: if you reintroduce the idea of absentmindedness, which acts as a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: go-between, you will see this profound comic element uniting with the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: most superficial type. Yes, indeed, these whimsical wild enthusiasts,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: these madmen who are yet so strangely reasonable, excite us to laughter
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: by playing on the same chords within ourselves, by setting in motion
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the same inner mechanism, as does the victim of a practical joke or the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: passer-by who slips down in the street. They, too, are runners who fall
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and simple souls who are being hoaxed--runners after the ideal who
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: stumble over realities, child-like dreamers for whom life delights to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: lie in wait. But, above all, they are past-masters in absentmindedness,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: with this superiority over their fellows that their absentmindedness is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: systematic and organised around one central idea, and that their
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: mishaps are also quite coherent, thanks to the inexorable logic which
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: reality applies to the correction of dreams, so that they kindle in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: those around them, by a series of cumulative effects, a hilarity
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: capable of unlimited expansion.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Now, let us go a little further. Might not certain vices have the same
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: relation to character that the rigidity of a fixed idea has to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: intellect? Whether as a moral kink or a crooked twist given to the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: will, vice has often the appearance of a curvature of the soul.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Doubtless there are vices into which the soul plunges deeply with all
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: its pregnant potency, which it rejuvenates and drags along with it into
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a moving circle of reincarnations. Those are tragic vices. But the vice
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: capable of making us comic is, on the contrary, that which is brought
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: from without, like a ready-made frame into which we are to step. It
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: lends us its own rigidity instead of borrowing from us our flexibility.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: We do not render it more complicated; on the contrary, it simplifies
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: us. Here, as we shall see later on in the concluding section of this
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: study, lies the essential difference between comedy and drama. A drama,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: even when portraying passions or vices that bear a name, so completely
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: incorporates them in the person that their names are forgotten, their
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: general characteristics effaced, and we no longer think of them at all,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: but rather of the person in whom they are assimilated; hence, the title
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of a drama can seldom be anything else than a proper noun. On the other
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: hand, many comedies have a common noun as their title: l'Avare, le
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Joueur, etc. Were you asked to think of a play capable of being called
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: le Jaloux, for instance, you would find that Sganarelle or George
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Dandin would occur to your mind, but not Othello: le Jaloux could only
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: be the title of a comedy. The reason is that, however intimately vice,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: when comic, is associated with persons, it none the less retains its
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: simple, independent existence, it remains the central character,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: present though invisible, to which the characters in flesh and blood on
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the stage are attached. At times it delights in dragging them down with
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: its own weight and making them share in its tumbles. More frequently,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: however, it plays on them as on an instrument or pulls the strings as
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: though they were puppets. Look closely: you will find that the art of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the comic poet consists in making us so well acquainted with the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: particular vice, in introducing us, the spectators, to such a degree of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: intimacy with it, that in the end we get hold of some of the strings of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the marionette with which he is playing, and actually work them
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ourselves; this it is that explains part of the pleasure we feel. Here,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: too, it is really a kind of automatism that makes us laugh--an
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: automatism, as we have already remarked, closely akin to mere
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: absentmindedness. To realise this more fully, it need only be noted
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: that a comic character is generally comic in proportion to his
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ignorance of himself. The comic person is unconscious. As though
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: wearing the ring of Gyges with reverse effect, he becomes invisible to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: himself while remaining visible to all the world. A character in a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: tragedy will make no change in his conduct because he will know how it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is judged by us; he may continue therein, even though fully conscious
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of what he is and feeling keenly the horror he inspires in us. But a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: defect that is ridiculous, as soon as it feels itself to be so,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: endeavours to modify itself, or at least to appear as though it did.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Were Harpagon to see us laugh at his miserliness, I do not say that he
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: would get rid of it, but he would either show it less or show it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: differently. Indeed, it is in this sense only that laughter "corrects
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: men's manners." It makes us at once endeavour to appear what we ought
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to be, what some day we shall perhaps end in being.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: It is unnecessary to carry this analysis any further. From the runner
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: who falls to the simpleton who is hoaxed, from a state of being hoaxed
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to one of absentmindedness, from absentmindedness to wild enthusiasm,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: from wild enthusiasm to various distortions of character and will, we
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: have followed the line of progress along which the comic becomes more
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and more deeply imbedded in the person, yet without ceasing, in its
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: subtler manifestations, to recall to us some trace of what we noticed
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: in its grosser forms, an effect of automatism and of inelasticity. Now
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: we can obtain a first glimpse--a distant one, it is true, and still
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: hazy and confused--of the laughable side of human nature and of the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ordinary function of laughter.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: What life and society require of each of us is a constantly alert
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: attention that discerns the outlines of the present situation, together
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: with a certain elasticity of mind and body to enable us to adapt
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ourselves in consequence. TENSION and ELASTICITY are two forces,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: mutually complementary, which life brings into play. If these two
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: forces are lacking in the body to any considerable extent, we have
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: sickness and infirmity and accidents of every kind. If they are lacking
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: in the mind, we find every degree of mental deficiency, every variety
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of insanity. Finally, if they are lacking in the character, we have
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: cases of the gravest inadaptability to social life, which are the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: sources of misery and at times the causes of crime. Once these elements
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of inferiority that affect the serious side of existence are
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: removed--and they tend to eliminate themselves in what has been called
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the struggle for life--the person can live, and that in common with
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: other persons. But society asks for something more; it is not satisfied
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: with simply living, it insists on living well. What it now has to dread
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is that each one of us, content with paying attention to what affects
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the essentials of life, will, so far as the rest is concerned, give way
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to the easy automatism of acquired habits. Another thing it must fear
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is that the members of whom it is made up, instead of aiming after an
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: increasingly delicate adjustment of wills which will fit more and more
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: perfectly into one another, will confine themselves to respecting
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: simply the fundamental conditions of this adjustment: a cut-and-dried
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: agreement among the persons will not satisfy it, it insists on a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: constant striving after reciprocal adaptation. Society will therefore
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: be suspicious of all INELASTICITY of character, of mind and even of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: body, because it is the possible sign of a slumbering activity as well
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: as of an activity with separatist tendencies, that inclines to swerve
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: from the common centre round which society gravitates: in short,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: because it is the sign of an eccentricity. And yet, society cannot
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: intervene at this stage by material repression, since it is not
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: affected in a material fashion. It is confronted with something that
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: makes it uneasy, but only as a symptom--scarcely a threat, at the very
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: most a gesture. A gesture, therefore, will be its reply. Laughter must
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: be something of this kind, a sort of SOCIAL GESTURE. By the fear which
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: it inspires, it restrains eccentricity, keeps constantly awake and in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: mutual contact certain activities of a secondary order which might
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: retire into their shell and go to sleep, and, in short, softens down
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: whatever the surface of the social body may retain of mechanical
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: inelasticity. Laughter, then, does not belong to the province of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: esthetics alone, since unconsciously (and even immorally in many
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: particular instances) it pursues a utilitarian aim of general
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: improvement. And yet there is something esthetic about it, since the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comic comes into being just when society and the individual, freed from
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the worry of self-preservation, begin to regard themselves as works of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: art. In a word, if a circle be drawn round those actions and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: dispositions--implied in individual or social life--to which their
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: natural consequences bring their own penalties, there remains outside
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: this sphere of emotion and struggle--and within a neutral zone in which
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: man simply exposes himself to man's curiosity--a certain rigidity of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: body, mind and character, that society would still like to get rid of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: in order to obtain from its members the greatest possible degree of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: elasticity and sociability. This rigidity is the comic, and laughter is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: its corrective.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Still, we must not accept this formula as a definition of the comic. It
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is suitable only for cases that are elementary, theoretical and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: perfect, in which the comic is free from all adulteration. Nor do we
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: offer it, either, as an explanation. We prefer to make it, if you will,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the leitmotiv which is to accompany all our explanations. We must ever
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: keep it in mind, though without dwelling on it too much, somewhat as a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: skilful fencer must think of the discontinuous movements of the lesson
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: whilst his body is given up to the continuity of the fencing-match. We
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: will now endeavour to reconstruct the sequence of comic forms, taking
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: up again the thread that leads from the horseplay of a clown up to the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: most refined effects of comedy, following this thread in its often
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: unforeseen windings, halting at intervals to look around, and finally
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: getting back, if possible, to the point at which the thread is dangling
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and where we shall perhaps find--since the comic oscillates between
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: life and art--the general relation that art bears to life.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: III
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Let us begin at the simplest point. What is a comic physiognomy? Where
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: does a ridiculous expression of the face come from? And what is, in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: this case, the distinction between the comic and the ugly? Thus stated,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the question could scarcely be answered in any other than an arbitrary
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: fashion. Simple though it may appear, it is, even now, too subtle to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: allow of a direct attack. We should have to begin with a definition of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ugliness, and then discover what addition the comic makes to it; now,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ugliness is not much easier to analyse than is beauty. However, we will
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: employ an artifice which will often stand us in good stead. We will
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: exaggerate the problem, so to speak, by magnifying the effect to the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: point of making the cause visible. Suppose, then, we intensify ugliness
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to the point of deformity, and study the transition from the deformed
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to the ridiculous.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Now, certain deformities undoubtedly possess over others the sorry
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: privilege of causing some persons to laugh; some hunchbacks, for
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: instance, will excite laughter. Without at this point entering into
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: useless details, we will simply ask the reader to think of a number of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: deformities, and then to divide them into two groups: on the one hand,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: those which nature has directed towards the ridiculous; and on the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: other, those which absolutely diverge from it. No doubt he will hit
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: upon the following law: A deformity that may become comic is a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: deformity that a normally built person, could successfully imitate.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Is it not, then, the case that the hunchback suggests the appearance of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a person who holds himself badly? His back seems to have contracted an
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ugly stoop. By a kind of physical obstinacy, by rigidity, in a word, it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: persists in the habit it has contracted. Try to see with your eyes
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: alone. Avoid reflection, and above all, do not reason. Abandon all your
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: prepossessions; seek to recapture a fresh, direct and primitive
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: impression. The vision you will reacquire will be one of this kind. You
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: will have before you a man bent on cultivating a certain rigid
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: attitude--whose body, if one may use the expression, is one vast grin.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Now, let us go back to the point we wished to clear up. By toning down
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a deformity that is laughable, we ought to obtain an ugliness that is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comic. A laughable expression of the face, then, is one that will make
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: us think of something rigid and, so to speak, coagulated, in the wonted
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: mobility of the face. What we shall see will be an ingrained twitching
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: or a fixed grimace. It may be objected that every habitual expression
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of the face, even when graceful and beautiful, gives us this same
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: impression of something stereotyped? Here an important distinction must
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: be drawn. When we speak of expressive beauty or even expressive
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ugliness, when we say that a face possesses expression, we mean
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: expression that may be stable, but which we conjecture to be mobile. It
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: maintains, in the midst of its fixity, a certain indecision in which
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: are obscurely portrayed all possible shades of the state of mind it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: expresses, just as the sunny promise of a warm day manifests itself in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the haze of a spring morning. But a comic expression of the face is one
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: that promises nothing more than it gives. It is a unique and permanent
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: grimace. One would say that the person's whole moral life has
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: crystallised into this particular cast of features. This is the reason
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: why a face is all the more comic, the more nearly it suggests to us the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: idea of some simple mechanical action in which its personality would
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: for ever be absorbed. Some faces seem to be always engaged in weeping,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: others in laughing or whistling, others, again, in eternally blowing an
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: imaginary trumpet, and these are the most comic faces of all. Here
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: again is exemplified the law according to which the more natural the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: explanation of the cause, the more comic is the effect. Automatism,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: inelasticity, habit that has been contracted and maintained, are
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: clearly the causes why a face makes us laugh. But this effect gains in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: intensity when we are able to connect these characteristics with some
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: deep-seated cause, a certain fundamental absentmindedness, as though
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the soul had allowed itself to be fascinated and hypnotised by the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: materiality of a simple action.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: We shall now understand the comic element in caricature. However
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: regular we may imagine a face to be, however harmonious its lines and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: supple its movements, their adjustment is never altogether perfect:
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: there will always be discoverable the signs of some impending bias, the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: vague suggestion of a possible grimace, in short some favourite
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: distortion towards which nature seems to be particularly inclined. The
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: art of the caricaturist consists in detecting this, at times,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: imperceptible tendency, and in rendering it visible to all eyes by
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: magnifying it. He makes his models grimace, as they would do themselves
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: if they went to the end of their tether. Beneath the skin-deep harmony
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of form, he divines the deep-seated recalcitrance of matter. He
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: realises disproportions and deformations which must have existed in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: nature as mere inclinations, but which have not succeeded in coming to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a head, being held in check by a higher force. His art, which has a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: touch of the diabolical, raises up the demon who had been overthrown by
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the angel. Certainly, it is an art that exaggerates, and yet the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: definition would be very far from complete were exaggeration alone
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: alleged to be its aim and object, for there exist caricatures that are
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: more lifelike than portraits, caricatures in which the exaggeration is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: scarcely noticeable, whilst, inversely, it is quite possible to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: exaggerate to excess without obtaining a real caricature. For
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: exaggeration to be comic, it must not appear as an aim, but rather as a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: means that the artist is using in order to make manifest to our eyes
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the distortions which he sees in embryo. It is this process of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: distortion that is of moment and interest. And that is precisely why we
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: shall look for it even in those elements of the face that are incapable
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of movement, in the curve of a nose or the shape of an ear. For, in our
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: eyes, form is always the outline of a movement. The caricaturist who
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: alters the size of a nose, but respects its ground plan, lengthening
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: it, for instance, in the very direction in which it was being
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: lengthened by nature, is really making the nose indulge in a grin.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Henceforth we shall always look upon the original as having determined
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to lengthen itself and start grinning. In this sense, one might say
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: that Nature herself often meets with the successes of a caricaturist.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: In the movement through which she has slit that mouth, curtailed that
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: chin and bulged out that cheek, she would appear to have succeeded in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: completing the intended grimace, thus outwitting the restraining
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: supervision of a more reasonable force. In that case, the face we laugh
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: at is, so to speak, its own caricature.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: To sum up, whatever be the doctrine to which our reason assents, our
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: imagination has a very clear-cut philosophy of its own: in every human
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: form it sees the effort of a soul which is shaping matter, a soul which
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is infinitely supple and perpetually in motion, subject to no law of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: gravitation, for it is not the earth that attracts it. This soul
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: imparts a portion of its winged lightness to the body it animates: the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: immateriality which thus passes into matter is what is called
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: gracefulness. Matter, however, is obstinate and resists. It draws to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: itself the ever-alert activity of this higher principle, would fain
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: convert it to its own inertia and cause it to revert to mere
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: automatism. It would fain immobilise the intelligently varied movements
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of the body in stupidly contracted grooves, stereotype in permanent
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: grimaces the fleeting expressions of the face, in short imprint on the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: whole person such an attitude as to make it appear immersed and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: absorbed in the materiality of some mechanical occupation instead of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ceaselessly renewing its vitality by keeping in touch with a living
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ideal. Where matter thus succeeds in dulling the outward life of the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: soul, in petrifying its movements and thwarting its gracefulness, it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: achieves, at the expense of the body, an effect that is comic. If,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: then, at this point we wished to define the comic by comparing it with
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: its contrary, we should have to contrast it with gracefulness even more
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: than with beauty. It partakes rather of the unsprightly than of the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: unsightly, of RIGIDNESS rather than of UGLINESS.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: IV
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: We will now pass from the comic element in FORMS to that in GESTURES
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and MOVEMENTS. Let us at once state the law which seems to govern all
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the phenomena of this kind. It may indeed be deduced without any
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: difficulty from the considerations stated above. THE ATTITUDES,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: GESTURES AND MOVEMENTS OF THE HUMAN BODY ARE LAUGHABLE IN EXACT
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: PROPORTION AS THAT BODY REMINDS US OF A MERE MACHINE. There is no need
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to follow this law through the details of its immediate applications,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: which are innumerable. To verify it directly, it would be sufficient to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: study closely the work of comic artists, eliminating entirely the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: element of caricature, and omitting that portion of the comic which is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: not inherent in the drawing itself. For, obviously, the comic element
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: in a drawing is often a borrowed one, for which the text supplies all
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the stock-in-trade. I mean that the artist may be his own understudy in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the shape of a satirist, or even a playwright, and that then we laugh
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: far less at the drawings themselves than at the satire or comic
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: incident they represent. But if we devote our whole attention to the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: drawing with the firm resolve to think of nothing else, we shall
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: probably find that it is generally comic in proportion to the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: clearness, as well as the subtleness, with which it enables us to see a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: man as a jointed puppet. The suggestion must be a clear one, for inside
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the person we must distinctly perceive, as though through a glass, a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: set-up mechanism. But the suggestion must also be a subtle one, for the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: general appearance of the person, whose every limb has been made rigid
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: as a machine, must continue to give us the impression of a living
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: being. The more exactly these two images, that of a person and that of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a machine, fit into each other, the more striking is the comic effect,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and the more consummate the art of the draughtsman. The originality of

text: Before going further, let us halt a moment and glance around. As we
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: like the carriage. Or else we might think of an immense avenue such as
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

text: Here we have the first illustration of a law which will appear with
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: increasing distinctness as we proceed with our task. When a musician
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: strikes a note on an instrument, other notes start up of themselves,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: relations, which coalesce with it and determine its quality. These are
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: what are called in physics the overtones of the fundamental note. It
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: would seem that comic fancy, even in its most far-fetched inventions,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: obeys a similar law. For instance, consider this comic note: appearance
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: seeking to triumph over reality. If our analysis is correct, this note
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: must have as its overtones the body tantalising the mind, the body
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: taking precedence of the mind. No sooner, then, does the comic poet
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: strike the first note than he will add the second on to it,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: involuntarily and instinctively. In other words, HE WILL DUPLICATE WHAT
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri
