author: Bergson, Henri

text: All these witticisms are constructed on the same model. We might make
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: up any number of them, when once we are in possession of the recipe.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: But the art of the story-teller or the playwright does not merely
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: consist in concocting jokes. The difficulty lies in giving to a joke
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: its power of suggestion, i.e. in making it acceptable. And we only do
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: accept it either because it seems to be the natural product of a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: particular state of mind or because it is in keeping with the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: circumstances of the case. For instance, we are aware that M. Perrichon
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is greatly excited on the occasion of his first railway journey. The
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: times in the lessons repeated by the girl before her father; it makes
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: us think of such a repetition. Lastly, admiration of the governmental
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: machine might, at a pinch, be extended to the point of making us
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: name, and that the function gets carried on independently of the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: functionary.

author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: We have now reached a point very far from the original cause of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: laughter. Many a comic form, that cannot be explained by itself, can
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: indeed only be understood from its resemblance to another, which only
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: makes us laugh by reason of its relationship with a third, and so on
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: indefinitely, so that psychological analysis, however luminous and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: searching, will go astray unless it holds the thread along which the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comic impression has travelled from one end of the series to the other.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Where does this progressive continuity come from? What can be the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: driving force, the strange impulse which causes the comic to glide thus
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: from image to image, farther and farther away from the starting-point,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: until it is broken up and lost in infinitely remote analogies? But what
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is that force which divides and subdivides the branches of a tree into
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: smaller boughs and its roots into radicles? An inexorable law dooms
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: every living energy, during the brief interval allotted to it in time,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to cover the widest possible extent in space. Now, comic fancy is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: indeed a living energy, a strange plant that has nourished on the stony
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: portions of the social soil, until such time as culture should allow it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to vie with the most refined products of art. True, we are far from
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: we shall draw nearer to it, though without attaining to it completely,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: in the following chapter. Below art, we find artifice, and it is this
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: subject. Perhaps we ought even to carry simplification still farther,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: fainter and fainter breaths by a past that is ever receding. In any
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: few carefully chosen cases, is liable at any moment to be met and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

text: overthrown by the first unsuitable instance that comes along.

author: Bergson, Henri

text: But why is it we laugh at this mechanical arrangement? It is doubtless
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: strange that the history of a person or of a group should sometimes
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: appear like a game worked by strings, or gearings, or springs; but from
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: what source does the special character of this strangeness arise? What
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is it that makes it laughable? To this question, which we have already
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: propounded in various forms, our answer must always be the same. The
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: rigid mechanism which we occasionally detect, as a foreign body, in the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: living continuity of human affairs is of peculiar interest to us as
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: being a kind of ABSENTMINDEDNESS on the part of life. Were events
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: unceasingly mindful of their own course, there would be no
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: coincidences, no conjunctures and no circular series; everything would
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: evolve and progress continuously. And were all men always attentive to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: life, were we constantly keeping in touch with others as well as with
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ourselves, nothing within us would ever appear as due to the working of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: strings or springs. The comic is that side of a person which reveals
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: his likeness to a thing, that aspect of human events which, through its
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: peculiar inelasticity, conveys the impression of pure mechanism, of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: automatism, of movement without life. Consequently it expresses an
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: individual or collective imperfection which calls for an immediate
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: corrective. This corrective is laughter, a social gesture that singles
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: out and represses a special kind of absentmindedness in men and in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: events.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: But this in turn tempts us to make further investigations. So far, we
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: have spent our time in rediscovering, in the diversions of the grownup
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: man, those mechanical combinations which amused him as a child. Our
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: methods, in fact, have been entirely empirical. Let us now attempt to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: frame a full and methodical theory, by seeking, as it were, at the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: fountainhead, the changeless and simple archetypes of the manifold and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: transient practices of the comic stage. Comedy, we said, combines
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: events so as to introduce mechanism into the outer forms of life. Let
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: us now ascertain in what essential characteristics life, when viewed
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: from without, seems to contrast with mere mechanism. We shall only
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: have, then, to turn to the opposite characteristics, in order to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: discover the abstract formula, this time a general and complete one,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: for every real and possible method of comedy.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Life presents itself to us as evolution in time and complexity in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: space. Regarded in time, it is the continuous evolution of a being ever
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: growing older; it never goes backwards and never repeats anything.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Considered in space, it exhibits certain coexisting elements so closely
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: interdependent, so exclusively made for one another, that not one of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: them could, at the same time, belong to two different organisms: each
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: living being is a closed system of phenomena, incapable of interfering
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: with other systems. A continual change of aspect, the irreversibility
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of the order of phenomena, the perfect individuality of a perfectly
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: self-contained series: such, then, are the outward
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: characteristics--whether real or apparent is of little moment--which
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: distinguish the living from the merely mechanical. Let us take the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: counterpart of each of these: we shall obtain three processes which
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: might be called REPETITION, INVERSION, and RECIPROCAL INTERFERENCE OF
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: SERIES. Now, it is easy to see that these are also the methods of light
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comedy, and that no others are possible.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: As a matter of fact, we could discover them, as ingredients of varying
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: importance, in the composition of all the scenes we have just been
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: considering, and, a fortiori, in the children's games, the mechanism of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: which they reproduce. The requisite analysis would, however, delay us
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: too long, and it is more profitable to study them in their purity by
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: taking fresh examples. Nothing could be easier, for it is in their pure
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: state that they are found both in classic comedy and in contemporary
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: plays.

text: 1. REPETITION.-Our present problem no longer deals, like the preceding
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: one, with a word or a sentence repeated by an individual, but rather
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: with a situation, that is, a combination of circumstances, which recurs
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: several times in its original form and thus contrasts with the changing
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: stream of life. Everyday experience supplies us with this type of the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comic, though only in a rudimentary state. Thus, you meet a friend in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the street whom you have not seen for an age; there is nothing comic in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the situation. If, however, you meet, him again the same day, and then
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a third and a fourth time, you may laugh at the "coincidence." Now,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: picture to yourself a series of imaginary events which affords a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: tolerably fair illusion of life, and within this ever-moving series
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: imagine one and the same scene reproduced either by the same characters
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: or by different ones: again you will have a coincidence, though a far
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: more extraordinary one.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Such are the repetitions produced on the stage. They are the more
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: laughable in proportion as the scene repeated is more complex and more
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: naturally introduced--two conditions which seem mutually exclusive, and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: which the play-writer must be clever enough to reconcile.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Contemporary light comedy employs this method in every shape and form.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: One of the best-known examples consists in bringing a group of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: characters, act after act, into the most varied surroundings, so as to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: reproduce, under ever fresh circumstances, one and the same series of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: incidents or accidents more or less symmetrically identical.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: In several of Moliere's plays we find one and the same arrangement of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: events repeated right through the comedy from beginning to end. Thus,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the Ecole des femmes does nothing more than reproduce and repeat a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: single incident in three tempi: first tempo, Horace tells Arnolphe of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the plan he has devised to deceive Agnes's guardian, who turns out to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: be Arnolphe himself; second tempo, Arnolphe thinks he has checkmated
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the move; third tempo, Agnes contrives that Horace gets all the benefit
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of Arnolphe's precautionary measures. There is the same symmetrical
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: repetition in the Ecole des marts, in L'Etourdi, and above all in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: George Dandin, where the same effect in three tempi is again met with:
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: first tempo, George Dandin discovers that his wife is unfaithful;
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: second tempo, he summons his father--and mother-in-law to his
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: assistance; third tempo, it is George Dandin himself, after all, who
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: has to apologise.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: At times the same scene is reproduced with groups of different
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: characters. Then it not infrequently happens that the first group
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: consists of masters and the second of servants. The latter repeat in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: another key a scene already played by the former, though the rendering
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is naturally less refined. A part of the Depit amoureux is constructed
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: on this plan, as is also Amphitryon. In an amusing little comedy of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Benedix, Der Eigensinn, the order is inverted: we have the masters
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: reproducing a scene of stubbornness in which their servants have set
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the example.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: But, quite irrespective of the characters who serve as pegs for the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: arrangement of symmetrical situations, there seems to be a wide gulf
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: between classic comedy and the theatre of to-day. Both aim at
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: introducing a certain mathematical order into events, while none the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: less maintaining their aspect of likelihood, that is to say, of life.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: But the means they employ are different. The majority of light comedies
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of our day seek to mesmerise directly the mind of the spectator. For,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: however extraordinary the coincidence, it becomes acceptable from the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: very fact that it is accepted; and we do accept it, if we have been
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: gradually prepared for its reception. Such is often the procedure
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: adopted by contemporary authors. In Moliere's plays, on the contrary,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: it is the moods of the persons on the stage, not of the audience, that
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: make repetition seem natural. Each of the characters represents a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: certain force applied in a certain direction, and it is because these
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: forces, constant in direction, necessarily combine together in the same
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: way, that the same situation is reproduced. Thus interpreted, the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comedy of situation is akin to the comedy of character. It deserves to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: be called classic, if classic art is indeed that which does not claim
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to derive from the effect more than it has put into the cause.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: 2. Inversion.--This second method has so much analogy with the first
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: that we will merely define it without insisting on illustrations.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Picture to yourself certain characters in a certain situation: if you
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: reverse the situation and invert the roles, you obtain a comic scene.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: The double rescue scene in Le Voyage de M. Perrichon belongs to this
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: class. [Footnote: Labiche, "Le Voyage de M. Perrichon."] There is no
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: necessity, however, for both the identical scenes to be played before
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: us. We may be shown only one, provided the other is really in our
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: minds. Thus, we laugh at the prisoner at the bar lecturing the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: magistrate; at a child presuming to teach its parents; in a word, at
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: everything that comes under the heading of "topsyturvydom." Not
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: infrequently comedy sets before us a character who lays a trap in which
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: he is the first to be caught. The plot of the villain who is the victim
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of his own villainy, or the cheat cheated, forms the stock-in-trade of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a good many plays. We find this even in primitive farce. Lawyer
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Pathelin tells his client of a trick to outwit the magistrate; the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: client employs the self-same trick to avoid paying the lawyer. A
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: termagant of a wife insists upon her husband doing all the housework;
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: she has put down each separate item on a "rota." Now let her fall into
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a copper, her husband will refuse to drag her out, for "that is not
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: down on his 'rota.'" In modern literature we meet with hundreds of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: variations on the theme of the robber robbed. In every case the root
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: idea involves an inversion of roles, and a situation which recoils on
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the head of its author.

author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Here we apparently find the confirmation of a law, some illustrations
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of which we have already pointed out. When a comic scene has been
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: reproduced a number of times, it reaches the stage of being a classical
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: type or model. It becomes amusing in itself, quite apart from the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: causes which render it amusing. Henceforth, new scenes, which are not
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comic de jure, may become amusing de facto, on account of their partial
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: resemblance to this model. They call up in our mind a more or less
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: confused image which we know to be comical. They range themselves in a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: category representing an officially recognised type of the comic. The
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: scene of the "robber robbed" belongs to this class. It casts over a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: host of other scenes a reflection of the comic element it contains. In
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: be nothing amusing in the saying, "It serves you right, George Dandin,"
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: were it not for the comic overtones that take up and re-echo it.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: 3. We have dwelt at considerable length on repetition and inversion; we
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: now come to the reciprocal interference [Footnote: The word
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of two series of light-waves.] of series. This is a comic effect, the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the extraordinary variety of forms in which it appears on the stage.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Perhaps it might be defined as follows: A situation is invariably comic
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: when it belongs simultaneously to two altogether independent series of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: events and is capable of being interpreted in two entirely different
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: meanings at the same time.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: You will at once think of an equivocal situation. And the equivocal
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: situation is indeed one which permits of two different meanings at the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: same time, the one merely plausible, which is put forward by the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: actors, the other a real one, which is given by the public. We see the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: real meaning of the situation, because care has been taken to show us
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: every aspect of it; but each of the actors knows only one of these
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: aspects: hence the mistakes they make and the erroneous judgments they
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: pass both on what is going on around them and on what they are doing
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: themselves. We proceed from this erroneous judgment to the correct one,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: we waver between the possible meaning and the real, and it is this
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: mental seesaw between two contrary interpretations which is at first
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: apparent in the enjoyment we derive from an equivocal situation. It is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: natural that certain philosophers should have been specially struck by
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: this mental instability, and that some of them should regard the very

text: We will not carry any further this analysis of the methods of light
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comedy. Whether we find reciprocal interference of series, inversion,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: or repetition, we see that the objective is always the same--to obtain
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: what we have called a MECHANISATION of life. You take a set of actions
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and relations and repeat it as it is, or turn it upside down, or
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: transfer it bodily to another set with which it partially
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: coincides--all these being processes that consist in looking upon life
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: as a repeating mechanism, with reversible action and interchangeable
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: parts. Actual life is comedy just so far as it produces, in a natural
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: fashion, actions of the same kind,--consequently, just so far as it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: forgets itself, for were it always on the alert, it would be
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ever-changing continuity, irrevertible progress, undivided unity. And
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: things, just as the ludicrous in an individual character always results
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: events, however, is exceptional. Its results are slight. At any rate it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is incurable, so that it is useless to laugh at it. Therefore the idea
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: would never have occurred to any one of exaggerating that
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: absentmindedness, of converting it into a system and creating an art
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: for it, if laughter were not always a pleasure and mankind did not
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: pounce upon the slightest excuse for indulging in it. This is the real
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: explanation of light comedy, which holds the same relation to actual
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: life as does a jointed dancing-doll to a man walking,--being, as it is,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: than a game which, like all games, depends on a previously accepted
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

author: Bergson, Henri

text: There may be something artificial in making a special category for the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comic in words, since most of the varieties of the comic that we have
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: examined so far were produced through the medium of language. We must
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: make a distinction, however, between the comic EXPRESSED and the comic
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: CREATED by language. The former could, if necessary, be translated from
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: one language into another, though at the cost of losing the greater
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: portion of its significance when introduced into a fresh society
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: different in manners, in literature, and above all in association of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ideas. But it is generally impossible to translate the latter. It owes
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: its entire being to the structure of the sentence or to the choice of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the words. It does not set forth, by means of language, special cases
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of absentmindedness in man or in events. It lays stress on lapses of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: attention in language itself. In this case, it is language itself that
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: becomes comic.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Comic sayings, however, are not a matter of spontaneous generation; if
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: we laugh at them, we are equally entitled to laugh at their author.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: or expression has a comic virtue of its own. This is proved by the fact
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: that we find it very difficult, in the majority of these cases, to say
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: whom we are laughing at, although at times we have a dim, vague feeling
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: that there is some one in the background.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

text: makes us laugh at the person who utters it, and witty when it makes us
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Every witty remark, then, lends itself to an analysis, whose chemical
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: belongs: by this means you reduce the witty remark to its simplest
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: elements and obtain a full explanation of it.
