text: I
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: We have followed the comic along many of its winding channels in an
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: endeavour to discover how it percolates into a form, an attitude, or a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: gesture; a situation, an action, or an expression. The analysis of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comic CHARACTERS has now brought us to the most important part of our
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: task. It would also be the most difficult, had we yielded to the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: temptation of defining the laughable by a few striking--and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: consequently obvious--examples; for then, in proportion as we advanced
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: towards the loftiest manifestations of the comic, we should have found
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the facts slipping between the over-wide meshes of the definition
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: intended to retain them. But, as a matter of fact, we have followed the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: opposite plan, by throwing light on the subject from above. Convinced
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: that laughter has a social meaning and import, that the comic
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: expresses, above all else, a special lack of adaptability to society,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and that, in short, there is nothing comic apart from man, we have made
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: man and character generally our main objective. Our chief difficulty,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: therefore, has lain in explaining how we come to laugh at anything else
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: than character, and by what subtle processes of fertilisation,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: combination or amalgamation, the comic can worm its way into a mere
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: movement, an impersonal situation, or an independent phrase. This is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: what we have done so far. We started with the pure metal, and all our
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: endeavours have been directed solely towards reconstructing the ore. It
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is the metal itself we are now about to study. Nothing could be easier,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: for this time we have a simple element to deal with. Let us examine it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: closely and see how it reacts upon everything else.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: There are moods, we said, which move us as soon us as soon as we
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: perceive them, joys and sorrows with which we sympathise, passions and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: vices which call forth painful astonishment, terror or pity, in the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: beholder; in short, sentiments that are prolonged in sentimental
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: overtones from mind to mind. All this concerns the essentials of life.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: All this is serious, at times even tragic. Comedy can only begin at the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: point where our neighbour's personality ceases to affect us. It begins,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: in fact, with what might be called a growing callousness to social
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: life. Any individual is comic who automatically goes his own way
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: without troubling himself about getting into touch with the rest of his
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: fellow-beings. It is the part of laughter to reprove his
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: absentmindedness and wake him out of his dream. If it is permissible to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: compare important things with trivial ones, we would call to mind what
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: happens when a youth enters one of our military academies. After
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: getting through the dreaded ordeal of the examination, he finds the has
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: other ordeals to face, which his seniors have arranged with the object
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of fitting him for the new life he is entering upon, or, as they say,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of "breaking him into harness." Every small society that forms within
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the larger is thus impelled, by a vague kind of instinct, to devise
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: some method of discipline or "breaking in," so as to deal with the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: rigidity of habits that have been formed elsewhere and have now to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: undergo a partial modification. Society, properly so-called, proceeds
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: in exactly the same way. Each member must be ever attentive to his
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: social surroundings; he must model himself on his environment; in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: short, he must avoid shutting himself up in his own peculiar character
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: as a philosopher in his ivory tower. Therefore society holds suspended
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: over each individual member, if not the threat of correction, at all
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: events the prospect of a snubbing, which, although it is slight, is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: none the less dreaded. Such must be the function of laughter. Always
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: rather humiliating for the one against whom it is directed, laughter
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is, really and truly, a kind of social "ragging."
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Hence the equivocal nature of the comic. It belongs neither altogether
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to art nor altogether to life. On the one hand, characters in real life
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: would never make us laugh were we not capable of watching their
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: vagaries in the same way as we look down at a play from our seat in a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: box; they are only comic in our eyes because they perform a kind of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comedy before us. But, on the other hand, the pleasure caused by
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: laughter, even on the stage, is not an unadulterated enjoyment; it is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: not a pleasure that is exclusively esthetic or altogether
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: disinterested. It always implies a secret or unconscious intent, if not
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of each one of us, at all events of society as a whole. In laughter we
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: always find an unavowed intention to humiliate, and consequently to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: correct our neighbour, if not in his will, at least in his deed. This
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is the reason a comedy is far more like real life than a drama is. The
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: more sublime the drama, the more profound the analysis to which the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: poet has had to subject the raw materials of daily life in order to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: obtain the tragic element in its unadulterated form. On the contrary,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: it is only in its lower aspects, in light comedy and farce, that comedy
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is in striking contrast to reality: the higher it rises, the more it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: approximates to life; in fact, there are scenes in real life so closely
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: bordering on high-class comedy that the stage might adopt them without
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: changing a single word.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Hence it follows that the elements of comic character on the stage and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: in actual life will be the same. What are these elements? We shall find
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: no difficulty in deducing them. It has often been said that it is the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: TRIFLING faults of our fellow-men that make us laugh.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Evidently there is a considerable amount of truth in this opinion;
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: still, it cannot be regarded as altogether correct. First, as regards
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: faults, it is no easy matter to draw the line between the trifling and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the serious; maybe it is not because a fault is trifling that it makes
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: us laugh, but rather because it makes us laugh that we regard it as
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: trifling, for there is nothing disarms us like laughter. But we may go
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: even farther, and maintain that there are faults at which we laugh,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: even though fully aware that they are serious,--Harpagon's avarice, for
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: instance. And then, we may as well confess--though somewhat
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: reluctantly--that we laugh not only at the faults of our fellow-men,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: but also, at times, at their good qualities. We laugh at Alceste. The
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: objection may be urged that it is not the earnestness of Alceste that
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is ludicrous, but rather the special aspect which earnestness assumes
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: in his case, and, in short, a certain eccentricity that mars it in our
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: eyes. Agreed; but it is none the less true that this eccentricity in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Alceste, at which we laugh, MAKES HIS EARNESTNESS LAUGHABLE, and that
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is the main point. So we may conclude that the ludicrous is not always
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: an indication of a fault, in the moral meaning of the word, and if
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: critics insist on seeing a fault, even though a trifling one, in the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ludicrous, they must point out what it is here that exactly
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: distinguishes the trifling from the serious.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: The truth is, the comic character may, strictly speaking, be quite in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: accord with stern morality. All it has to do is to bring itself into
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: accord with society. The character of Alceste is that of a thoroughly
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: honest man. But then he is unsociable, and, on that very account,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ludicrous. A flexible vice may not be so easy to ridicule as a rigid
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: virtue. It is rigidity that society eyes with suspicion. Consequently,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: it is the rigidity of Alceste that makes us laugh, though here rigidity
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: stands for honesty. The man who withdraws into himself is liable to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ridicule, because the comic is largely made up of this very withdrawal.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: This accounts for the comic being so frequently dependent on the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: manners or ideas, or, to put it bluntly, on the prejudices, of a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: society.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: It must be acknowledged, however, to the credit of mankind, that there
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is no essential difference between the social ideal and the rule, that
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: it is the faults of others that make us laugh, provided we add that
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: they make us laugh by reason of their UNSOCIABILITY rather than of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: their IMMORALITY. What, then, are the faults capable of becoming
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ludicrous, and in what circumstances do we regard them as being too
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: serious to be laughed at?
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: We have already given an implicit answer to this question. The comic,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: we said, appeals to the intelligence, pure and simple; laughter is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: incompatible with emotion. Depict some fault, however trifling, in such
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a way as to arouse sympathy, fear, or pity; the mischief is done, it is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: impossible for us to laugh. On the other hand, take a downright
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: vice,--even one that is, generally speaking, of an odious nature,--you
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: may make it ludicrous if, by some suitable contrivance, you arrange so
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: that it leaves our emotions unaffected. Not that the vice must then be
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ludicrous, but it MAY, from that time forth, become so. IT MUST NOT
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: AROUSE OUR FEELINGS; that is the sole condition really necessary,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: though assuredly it is not sufficient.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: But, then, how will the comic poet set to work to prevent our feelings
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: being moved? The question is an embarrassing one. To clear it up
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: thoroughly, we should have to enter upon a rather novel line of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: investigation, to analyse the artificial sympathy which we bring with
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: us to the theatre, and determine upon the circumstances in which we
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: accept and those in which we refuse to share imaginary joys and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: sorrows. There is an art of lulling sensibility to sleep and providing
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: it with dreams, as happens in the case of a mesmerised person. And
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: there is also an art of throwing a wet blanket upon sympathy at the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: very moment it might arise, the result being that the situation, though
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a serious one, is not taken seriously. This latter art would appear to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: be governed by two methods, which are applied more or less
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: unconsciously by the comic poet. The first consists in ISOLATING,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: within the soul of the character, the feeling attributed to him, and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: making it a parasitic organism, so to speak, endowed with an
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: independent existence. As a general rule, an intense feeling
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: successively encroaches upon all other mental states and colours them
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: with its own peculiar hue; if, then, we are made to witness this
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: gradual impregnation, we finally become impregnated ourselves with a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: corresponding emotion. To employ a different image, an emotion may be
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: said to be dramatic and contagious when all the harmonics in it are
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: heard along with the fundamental note. It is because the actor thus
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: thrills throughout his whole being that the spectators themselves feel
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the thrill. On the contrary, in the case of emotion that leaves us
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: indifferent and that is about to become comic, there is always present
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a certain rigidity which prevents it from establishing a connection
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: with the rest of the soul in which it has taken up its abode. This
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: rigidity may be manifested, when the time comes, by puppet-like
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: movements, and then it will provoke laughter; but, before that, it had
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: already alienated our sympathy: how can we put ourselves in tune with a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: soul which is not in tune with itself? In Moliere's L'Avare we have a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: scene bordering upon drama. It is the one in which the borrower and the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: usurer, who have never seen each other, meet face to face and find that
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: they are son and father. Here we should be in the thick of a drama, if
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: only greed and fatherly affection, conflicting with each other in the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: soul of Harpagon, had effected a more or less original combination. But
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: such is not the case. No sooner has the interview come to an end than
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the father forgets everything. On meeting his son again he barely
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: alludes to the scene, serious though it has been: "You, my son, whom I
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: am good enough to forgive your recent escapade, etc." Greed has thus
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: passed close to all other feelings ABSENTMINDEDLY, without either
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: touching them or being touched. Although it has taken up its abode in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the soul and become master of the house, none the less it remains a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: stranger. Far different would be avarice of a tragic sort. We should
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: find it attracting and absorbing, transforming and assimilating the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: divers energies of the man: feelings and affections, likes and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: dislikes, vices and virtues, would all become something into which
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: avarice would breathe a new kind of life. Such seems to be the first
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: essential difference between high-class comedy and drama.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: There is a second, which is far more obvious and arises out of the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: first. When a mental state is depicted to us with the object of making
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: it dramatic, or even merely of inducing us to take it seriously, it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: gradually crystallises into ACTIONS which provide the real measure of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: its greatness. Thus, the miser orders his whole life with a view to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: acquiring wealth, and the pious hypocrite, though pretending to have
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: his eyes fixed upon heaven, steers most skilfully his course here
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: below. Most certainly, comedy does not shut out calculations of this
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: kind; we need only take as an example the very machinations of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Tartuffe. But that is what comedy has in common with drama; and in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: order to keep distinct from it, to prevent our taking a serious action
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: seriously, in short, in order to prepare us for laughter, comedy
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: utilises a method, the formula of which may be given as follows:
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: INSTEAD OF CONCENTRATING OUR ATTENTION ON ACTIONS, COMEDY DIRECTS IT
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: RATHER TO GESTURES. By GESTURES we here mean the attitudes, the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: movements and even the language by which a mental state expresses
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: itself outwardly without any aim or profit, from no other cause than a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: kind of inner itching. Gesture, thus defined, is profoundly different
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: from action. Action is intentional or, at any rate, conscious; gesture
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: slips out unawares, it is automatic. In action, the entire person is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: engaged; in gesture, an isolated part of the person is expressed,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: unknown to, or at least apart from, the whole of the personality.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Lastly--and here is the essential point--action is in exact proportion
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to the feeling that inspires it: the one gradually passes into the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: other, so that we may allow our sympathy or our aversion to glide along
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the line running from feeling to action and become increasingly
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: interested. About gesture, however, there is something explosive, which
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: awakes our sensibility when on the point of being lulled to sleep and,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: by thus rousing us up, prevents our taking matters seriously. Thus, as
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: soon as our attention is fixed on gesture and not on action, we are in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the realm of comedy. Did we merely take his actions into account,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Tartuffe would belong to drama: it is only when we take his gestures
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: into consideration that we find him comic. You may remember how he
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comes on to the stage with the words: "Laurent, lock up my hair-shirt
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and my scourge." He knows Dorine is listening to him, but doubtless he
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: would say the same if she were not there. He enters so thoroughly into
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the role of a hypocrite that he plays it almost sincerely. In this way,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and this way only, can he become comic. Were it not for this material
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: sincerity, were it not for the language and attitudes that his
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: long-standing experience as a hypocrite has transformed into natural
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: gestures, Tartuffe would be simply odious, because we should only think
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of what is meant and willed in his conduct. And so we see why action is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: essential in drama, but only accessory in comedy. In a comedy, we feel
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: any other situation might equally well have been chosen for the purpose
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of introducing the character; he would still have been the same man
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: though the situation were different. But we do not get this impression
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: in a drama. Here characters and situations are welded together, or
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: rather, events form part and parcel with the persons, so that were the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: drama to tell us a different story, even though the actors kept the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: same names, we should in reality be dealing with other persons.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: To sum up, whether a character is good or bad is of little moment:
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: granted he is unsociable, he is capable of becoming comic. We now see
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: that the seriousness of the case is of no importance either: whether
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: serious or trifling, it is still capable of making us laugh, provided
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: that care be taken not to arouse our emotions. Unsociability in the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: performer and insensibility in the spectator--such, in a word, are the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: two essential conditions. There is a third, implicit in the other two,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: which so far it has been the aim of our analysis to bring out.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: This third condition is automatism. We have pointed it out from the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: outset of this work, continually drawing attention to the following
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: point: what is essentially laughable is what is done automatically. In
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a vice, even in a virtue, the comic is that element by which the person
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: unwittingly betrays himself--the involuntary gesture or the unconscious
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: remark. Absentmindedness is always comical. Indeed, the deeper the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: absentmindedness the higher the comedy. Systematic absentmindedness,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: like that of Don Quixote, is the most comical thing imaginable: it is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the comic itself, drawn as nearly as possible from its very source.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Take any other comic character: however unconscious he may be of what
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: he says or does, he cannot be comical unless there be some aspect of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: his person of which he is unaware, one side of his nature which he
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: overlooks; on that account alone does he make us laugh. [Footnote: When
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the humorist laughs at himself, he is really acting a double part; the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: self who laughs is indeed conscious, but not the self who is laughed
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: at.] Profoundly comic sayings are those artless ones in which some vice
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: reveals itself in all its nakedness: how could it thus expose itself
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: were it capable of seeing itself as it is? It is not uncommon for a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comic character to condemn in general terms a certain line of conduct
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and immediately afterwards afford an example of it himself: for
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: instance, M. Jourdain's teacher of philosophy flying into a passion
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: after inveighing against anger; Vadius taking a poem from his pocket
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: after heaping ridicule on readers of poetry, etc. What is the object of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: such contradictions except to help us to put our finger on the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: obliviousness of the characters to their own actions? Inattention to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: self, and consequently to others, is what we invariably find. And if we
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: look at the matter closely, we see that inattention is here equivalent
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to what we have called unsociability. The chief cause of rigidity is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the neglect to look around--and more especially within oneself: how can
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a man fashion his personality after that of another if he does not
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: first study others as well as himself? Rigidity, automatism,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: absent-mindedness and unsociability are all inextricably entwined; and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: all serve as ingredients to the making up of the comic in character.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: In a word, if we leave on one side, when dealing with human
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: personality, that portion which interests our sensibility or appeals to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: our feeling, all the rest is capable of becoming comic, and the comic
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: will be proportioned to the rigidity. We formulated this idea at the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: outset of this work. We have verified it in its main results, and have
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: just applied it to the definition of comedy. Now we must get to closer
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: quarters, and show how it enables us to delimitate the exact position
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comedy occupies among all the other arts. In one sense it might be said
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: that all character is comic, provided we mean by character the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ready-made element in our personality, that mechanical element which
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: resembles a piece of clockwork wound up once for all and capable of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: working automatically. It is, if you will, that which causes us to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: imitate ourselves. And it is also, for that very reason, that which
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: enables others to imitate us. Every comic character is a type.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Inversely, every resemblance to a type has something comic in it.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Though we may long have associated with an individual without
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: discovering anything about him to laugh at, still, if advantage is t
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: taken of some accidental analogy to dub him with the name of a famous
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: hero of romance or drama, he will in our eyes border upon the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ridiculous, if only for a moment. And yet this hero of romance may not
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: be a comic character at all. But then it is comic to be like him. It is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: comic to wander out of one's own self. It is comic to fall into a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ready-made category. And what is most comic of all is to become a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: category oneself into which others will fall, as into a ready-made
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: frame; it is to crystallise into a stock character.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Thus, to depict characters, that is to say, general types, is the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: object of high-class comedy. This has often been said. But it is as
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: well to repeat it, since there could be no better definition of comedy.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Not only are we entitled to say that comedy gives us general types, but
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: we might add that it is the ONLY one of all the arts that aims at the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: general; so that once this objective has been attributed to it, we have
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: said all that it is and all that the rest cannot be. To prove that such
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is really the essence of comedy, and that it is in this respect opposed
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to tragedy, drama and the other forms of art, we should begin by
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: defining art in its higher forms: then, gradually coming down to comic
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: poetry, we should find that this latter is situated on the border-line
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: between art and life, and that, by the generality of its
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: subject-matter, it contrasts with the rest of the arts. We cannot here
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: plunge into so vast a subject of investigation; but we needs must
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: sketch its main outlines, lest we overlook what, to our mind, is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: essential on the comic stage.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: What is the object of art? Could reality come into direct contact with
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: sense and consciousness, could we enter into immediate communion with
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: things and with ourselves, probably art would be useless, or rather we
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: should all be artists, for then our soul would continually vibrate in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: perfect accord with nature. Our eyes, aided by memory, would carve out
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: in space and fix in time the most inimitable of pictures. Hewn in the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: living marble of the human form, fragments of statues, beautiful as the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: relics of antique statuary, would strike the passing glance. Deep in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: our souls we should hear the strains of our inner life's unbroken
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: melody,--a music that is ofttimes gay, but more frequently plaintive
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and always original. All this is around and within us, and yet no whit
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of it do we distinctly perceive. Between nature and ourselves, nay,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: between ourselves and our own consciousness a veil is interposed: a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: veil that is dense and opaque for the common herd,--thin, almost
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: transparent, for the artist and the poet. What fairy wove that veil?
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Was it done in malice or in friendliness? We had to live, and life
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: demands that we grasp things in their relations to our own needs. Life
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is action. Life implies the acceptance only of the UTILITARIAN side of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: things in order to respond to them by appropriate reactions: all other
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: impressions must be dimmed or else reach us vague and blurred. I look
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and I think I see, I listen and I think I hear, I examine myself and I
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: think I am reading the very depths of my heart. But what I see and hear
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of the outer world is purely and simply a selection made by my senses
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to serve as a light to my conduct; what I know of myself is what comes
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to the surface, what participates in my actions. My senses and my
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: consciousness, therefore, give me no more than a practical
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: simplification of reality. In the vision they furnish me of myself and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of things, the differences that are useless to man are obliterated, the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: resemblances that are useful to him are emphasised; ways are traced out
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: for me in advance, along which my activity is to travel. These ways are
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the ways which all mankind has trod before me. Things have been
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: classified with a view to the use I can derive from them. And it is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: this classification I perceive, far more clearly than the colour and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the shape of things. Doubtless man is vastly superior to the lower
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: animals in this respect. It is not very likely that the eye of a wolf
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: makes any distinction between a kid and a lamb; both appear t o the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: wolf as the same identical quarry, alike easy to pounce upon, alike
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: good to devour. We, for our part, make a distinction between a goat and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a sheep; but can we tell one goat from another, one sheep from another?
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: The INDIVIDUALITY of things or of beings escapes us, unless it is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: materially to our advantage to perceive it. Even when we do take note
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of it--as when we distinguish one man from another--it is not the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: individuality itself that the eye grasps, i.e., an entirely original
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: harmony of forms and colours, but only one or two features that will
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: make practical recognition easier.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: In short, we do not see the actual things themselves; in most cases we
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: confine ourselves to reading the labels affixed to them. This tendency,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the result of need, has become even more pronounced under the influence
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of speech; for words--with the exception of proper nouns--all denote
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: genera. The word, which only takes note of the most ordinary function
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and commonplace aspect of the thing, intervenes between it and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ourselves, and would conceal its form from our eyes, were that form not
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: already masked beneath the necessities that brought the word into
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: existence. Not only external objects, but even our own mental states,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: are screened from us in their inmost, their personal aspect, in the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: original life they possess. When we feel love or hatred, when we are
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: gay or sad, is it really the feeling itself that reaches our
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: consciousness with those innumerable fleeting shades of meaning and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: deep resounding echoes that make it something altogether our own? We
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: should all, were it so, be novelists or poets or musicians. Mostly,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: however, we perceive nothing but the outward display of our mental
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: state. We catch only the impersonal aspect of our feelings, that aspect
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: which speech has set down once for all because it is almost the same,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: in the same conditions, for all men. Thus, even in our own individual,
