author: Bergson, Henri

text: necessary to it because it is based on the division of labour. We mean
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the various trades, public services and professions. Each particular
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: profession impresses on its corporate members certain habits of mind
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and peculiarities of character in which they resemble each other and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: also distinguish themselves from the rest. Small societies are thus
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: formed within the bosom of Society at large. Doubtless they arise from
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the very organisation of Society as a whole. And yet, if they held too
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: much aloof, there would be a risk of their proving harmful to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: sociability.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Now, it is the business of laughter to repress any separatist tendency.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Its function is to convert rigidity into plasticity, to readapt the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: individual to the whole, in short, to round off the corners wherever
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: they are met with. Accordingly, we here find a species of the comic
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: whose varieties might be calculated beforehand. This we shall call the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: PROFESSIONAL COMIC.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Instead of taking up these varieties in detail, we prefer to lay stress
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: upon what they have in common. In the forefront we find professional
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: vanity. Each one of M. Jourdain's teachers exalts his own art above all
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the rest. In a play of Labiche there is a character who cannot
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: understand how it is possible to be anything else than a timber
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: merchant. Naturally he is a timber merchant himself. Note that vanity
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: here tends to merge into SOLEMNITY, in proportion to the degree of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: quackery there is in the profession under consideration. For it is a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: remarkable fact that the more questionable an art, science or
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: occupation is, the more those who practise it are inclined to regard
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: themselves as invested with a kind of priesthood and to claim that all
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: should bow before its mysteries. Useful professions are clearly meant
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: for the public, but those whose utility is more dubious can only
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: justify their existence by assuming that the public is meant for them:
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: now, this is just the illusion that lies at the root of solemnity.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Almost everything comic in Moliere's doctors comes from this source.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: They treat the patient as though he had been made for the doctors, and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: nature herself as an appendage to medicine.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Another form of this comic rigidity is what may be called PROFESSIONAL
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: CALLOUSNESS. The comic character is so tightly jammed into the rigid
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: frame of his functions that he has no room to move or to be moved like
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: other men. Only call to mind the answer Isabelle receives from Perrin
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Dandin, the judge, when she asks him how he can bear to look on when
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the poor wretches are being tortured: Bah! cela fait toujours passer
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: une heure ou deux.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: [Footnote: Bah! it always helps to while away an hour or two.]
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Does not Tartuffe also manifest a sort of professional callousness when
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: he says--it is true, by the mouth of Orgon: Et je verrais mourir frere,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: enfants, mere et femme, Que je m'en soucierais autant que de cela!
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: [Footnote: Let brother, children, mother and wife all die, what should
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: I care!]
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: The device most in use, however, for making a profession ludicrous is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to confine it, so to say, within the four corners of its own particular
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: jargon. Judge, doctor and soldier are made to apply the language of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: law, medicine and strategy to the everyday affairs of life, as though
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: they had became incapable of talking like ordinary people. As a rule,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: this kind of the ludicrous is rather coarse. It becomes more refined,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: however, as we have already said, if it reveals some peculiarity of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: character in addition to a professional habit. We will instance only
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Regnard's Joueur, who expresses himself with the utmost originality in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: terms borrowed from gambling, giving his valet the name of Hector, and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: calling his betrothed Pallas, du nom connu de la Dame de Pique;
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: [Footnote: Pallas, from the well-known name of the Queen of Spades.] or
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Moliere's Femmes savantes, where the comic element evidently consists
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: largely in the translation of ideas of a scientific nature into terms
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of feminine sensibility: "Epicure me plait..." (Epicurus is charming),
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: "J'aime les tourbillons" (I dote on vortices), etc. You have only to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: read the third act to find that Armande, Philaminte and Belise almost
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: invariably express themselves in this style.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Proceeding further in the same direction, we discover that there is
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: also such a thing as a professional logic, i.e. certain ways of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: reasoning that are customary in certain circles, which are valid for
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: these circles, but untrue for the rest of the public. Now, the contrast
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: between these two kinds of logic--one particular, the other
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: universal--produces comic effects of a special nature, on which we may
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: advantageously dwell at greater length. Here we touch upon a point of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: some consequence in the theory of laughter. We propose, therefore, to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: give the question a wider scope and consider it in its most general
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: aspect.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: IV
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Eager as we have been to discover the deep-seated cause of the comic,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: we have so far had to neglect one of its most striking phenomena. We
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: refer to the logic peculiar to the comic character and the comic group,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: a strange kind of logic, which, in some cases, may include a good deal
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of absurdity.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Theophile Gautier said that the comic in its extreme form was the logic
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of the absurd. More than one philosophy of laughter revolves round a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: like idea. Every comic effect, it is said, implies contradiction in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: some of its aspects. What makes us laugh is alleged to be the absurd
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: realised in concrete shape, a "palpable absurdity";--or, again, an
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: apparent absurdity, which we swallow for the moment only to rectify it
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: immediately afterwards;--or, better still, something absurd from one
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: point of view though capable of a natural explanation from another,
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: etc. All these theories may contain some portion of the truth; but, in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the first place, they apply only to certain rather obvious comic
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: effects, and then, even where they do apply, they evidently take no
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: account of the characteristic element of the laughable, that is, the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: PARTICULAR KIND of absurdity the comic contains when it does contain
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: something absurd. Is an immediate proof of this desired? You have only
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to choose one of these definitions and make up effects in accordance
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: with the formula: twice out of every three times there will be nothing
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: laughable in the effect obtained. So we see that absurdity, when met
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: with in the comic, is not absurdity IN GENERAL. It is an absurdity of a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: definite kind. It does not create the comic; rather, we might say that
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the comic infuses into it its own particular essence. It is not a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: cause, but an effect--an effect of a very special kind, which reflects
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the special nature of its cause. Now, this cause is known to us;
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: consequently we shall have no trouble in understanding the nature of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the effect.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Assume, when out for a country walk, that you notice on the top of a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: hill something that bears a faint resemblance to a large motionless
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: body with revolving arms. So far you do not know what it is, but you
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: begin to search amongst your IDEAS--that is to say, in the present
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: instance, amongst the recollections at your disposal--for that
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: recollection which will best fit in with what you see. Almost
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: immediately the image of a windmill comes into your mind: the object
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: before you is a windmill. No matter if, before leaving the house, you
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: have just been reading fairy-tales telling of giants with enormous
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: arms; for although common sense consists mainly in being able to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: remember, it consists even more in being able to forget. Common sense
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: represents the endeavour of a mind continually adapting itself anew and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: changing ideas when it changes objects. It is the mobility of the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: intelligence conforming exactly to the mobility of things. It is the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: moving continuity of our attention to life. But now, let us take Don
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Quixote setting out for the wars. The romances he has been reading all
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: tell of knights encountering, on the way, giant adversaries. He
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: therefore must needs encounter a giant. This idea of a giant is a
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: privileged recollection which has taken its abode in his mind and lies
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: there in wait, motionless, watching for an opportunity to sally forth
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: and become embodied in a thing. It IS BENT on entering the material
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: world, and so the very first object he sees bearing the faintest
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: resemblance to a giant is invested with the form of one. Thus Don
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Quixote sees giants where we see windmills. This is comical; it is also
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: absurd. But is it a mere absurdity,--an absurdity of an indefinite kind?
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: It is a very special inversion of common sense. It consists in seeking
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: to mould things on an idea of one's own, instead of moulding one's
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ideas on things,--in seeing before us what we are thinking of, instead
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of thinking of what we see. Good sense would have us leave all our
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: memories in their proper rank and file; then the appropriate memory
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: will every time answer the summons of the situation of the moment and
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: serve only to interpret it. But in Don Quixote, on the contrary, there
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: is one group of memories in command of all the rest and dominating the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: character itself: thus it is reality that now has to bow to
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: imagination, its only function being to supply fancy with a body. Once
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the illusion has been created, Don Quixote develops it logically enough
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: in all its consequences; he proceeds with the certainty and precision
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of a somnambulist who is acting his dream. Such, then, is the origin of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: his delusions, and such the particular logic which controls this
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: particular absurdity. Now, is this logic peculiar to Don Quixote?
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: We have shown that the comic character always errs through obstinacy of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: mind or of disposition, through absentmindedness, in short, through
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: automatism. At the root of the comic there is a sort of rigidity which
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: compels its victims to keep strictly to one path, to follow it straight
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: along, to shut their ears and refuse to listen. In Moliere's plays how
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: many comic scenes can be reduced to this simple type: A CHARACTER
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: FOLLOWING UP HIS ONE IDEA, and continually recurring to it in spite of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: incessant interruptions! The transition seems to take place
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: imperceptibly from the man who will listen to nothing to the one who
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: will see nothing, and from this latter to the one who sees only what he
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: wants to see. A stubborn spirit ends by adjusting things to its own way
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of thinking, instead of accommodating its thoughts to the things. So
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: every comic character is on the highroad to the above-mentioned
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: illusion, and Don Quixote furnishes us with the general type of comic
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: absurdity.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Is there a name for this inversion of common sense? Doubtless it may be
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: found, in either an acute or a chronic form, in certain types of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: insanity. In many of its aspects it resembles a fixed idea. But neither
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: insanity in general, nor fixed ideas in particular, are provocative of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: laughter: they are diseases, and arouse our pity.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Laughter, as we have seen, is incompatible with emotion. If there
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: exists a madness that is laughable, it can only be one compatible with
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the general health of the mind,--a sane type of madness, one might say.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Now, there is a sane state of the mind that resembles madness in every
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: respect, in which we find the same associations of ideas as we do in
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: lunacy, the same peculiar logic as in a fixed idea. This state is that
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of dreams. So either our analysis is incorrect, or it must be capable
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: of being stated in the following theorem: Comic absurdity is of the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: same nature as that of dreams.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: The behaviour of the intellect in a dream is exactly what we have just
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: been describing. The mind, enamoured of itself, now seeks in the outer
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: world nothing more than a pretext for realising its imaginations. A
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: confused murmur of sounds still reaches the ear, colours enter the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: field of vision, the senses are not completely shut in. But the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: dreamer, instead of appealing to the whole of his recollections for the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: interpretation of what his senses perceive, makes use of what he
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: perceives to give substance to the particular recollection he favours:
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: thus, according to the mood of the dreamer and the idea that fills his
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: imagination at the time, a gust of wind blowing down the chimney
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: becomes the howl of a wild beast or a tuneful melody. Such is the
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: ordinary mechanism of illusion in dreams.
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: Now, if comic illusion is similar to dream illusion, if the logic of
title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
author: Bergson, Henri

text: the comic is the logic of dreams, we may expect to discover in the

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic

title: Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic
